title: Enhancing Consent for Alzheimer's Research
description_brief: The purpose of this study is to evaluate the efficacy of an enhanced consent procedure for patients with mild-to-moderate Alzheimer disease, and to identify factors and patient characteristics that predict the degree to which enhanced consent is more beneficial than routine consent procedures.
description_detailed:
Alzheimer disease can impair the capacity of patients to give informed consent for research participation. Studies of informed consent involving other patient populations suggest better understanding of consent-relevant information may be achieved through modifications in the consent delivery process, including incorporation of multimedia learning tools into the consent discussion.

In the present study, participants with Alzheimer disease and age-comparable healthy participants will be randomly assigned to review a hypothetical research protocol via routine or enhanced consent procedures. Participants will also complete standard cognitive and other rating scales so that we can characterize the sample, as well as evaluate the degree to which specific characteristics may be associated with need for enhanced consent procedures. Advances in the methods to optimize the informed consent process should enable future research participants to make more fully informed decisions.

groups.title: Enhanced Consent - A
groups.description:
The intervention was an enhanced consent process, including a multimedia aid for a moderate risk hypothetical protocol

Enhanced Consent Procedure: This is a procedure involving use of multimedia materials, as well as standard review with research staff, to see if the research consent procedure can be improved

groups.title: Enhanced Consent - B
groups.description:
The intervention was an enhanced consent process, including multimedia aide for a higher risk hypothetical protocol

Enhanced Consent Procedure: This is a procedure involving use of multimedia materials, as well as standard review with research staff, to see if the research consent procedure can be improved

groups.title: Routine Consent - A
groups.description:
This was a comparison condition - a routine consent process, including a printed consent document, for a moderate risk hypothetical protocol

Routine Consent Procedure: This is a procedure designed to be in accord with standard research consent practices (and lacks multimedia aids)

groups.title: Routine Consent - B
groups.description:
This was a comparison condition - a routine consent process, including a printed consent document, for a higher risk hypothetical protocol

Routine Consent Procedure: This is a procedure designed to be in accord with standard research consent practices (and lacks multimedia aids)

baselineCharacteristicsModule.populationDescription: 259 subjects met inclusion/exclusion criteria, but 8 withdrew prior to the randomization (only two due to study - i.e. 2 found assessments too frustrating); 3 additional subjects had missing data key outcomes; resulting in 248 subjects in the final data analysis..

categories.title: Native Hawaiian or Other Pacific Islander

measures.title: Region of Enrollment
measures.description: All participants were recruited and seen in the San Diego, CA metropolitan area.

outcomeMeasures.title: Level of Understanding
outcomeMeasures.description:
Modified version of the MacArthur Competence Assessment Tool for Clinical Research (MacCAT-CR) Understanding subscale.

Minimum value = 0, Maximum value = 26; higher scores represent better performance
outcomeMeasures.populationDescription: 114 people with Alzheimer's disease (AD); 134 non-neuropsychiatric comparison (NC) subjects; the effects of routine vs. enhanced consent and moderate vs. higher risk were analyzed within diagnostic groups separately
outcomeMeasures.unitOfMeasure: score on a scale (MacCAT-CR Und Trial 2)
outcomeMeasures.timeFrame: Within session - administered approximately 2-3 minutes after completion of the simulated consent process.

outcomeMeasures.title: Level of Satisfaction With Consent Process
outcomeMeasures.description:
Question - "The consent process was" rated from "Very easy" to "Very Hard"

1. Very Easy
2. Easy
3. No effect
4. Hard
5. Very hard Higher scores mean more difficult (less satisfaction) with the consent process

   * with 1 being "Very Easy" and 5 being "Very hard"
outcomeMeasures.populationDescription: Administered immediately after the MacCAT-CR Expression of a Choice subscale

1. = Yes

explanation_target: Reason: The study title and description state the intervention is an enhanced consent procedure (multimedia/organizational aids and re-explanation) intended to improve patients' comprehension/decisional capacity for research participation—not a therapeutic drug or diagnostic test—so it does not fit the disease-targeted biologic, disease-targeted small molecule, cognitive enhancer, or neuropsychiatric-symptom categories. citeturn0search3turn0search2

Act: Key extracted details — Intervention: Enhanced Consent Procedure versus Routine Consent Procedure (listed as 'Other' interventions); Population: patients with mild-to-moderate Alzheimer disease (with age-comparable controls in some designs); Design: randomized comparison to evaluate efficacy of enhanced consent and predictors of benefit. No drug name, biologic, or placebo is described in the protocol. (Clinical trial record and grant summary). citeturn0search3turn0search2

Reflect: Classification check — this is a procedural/ethical intervention to improve informed consent capacity and not a therapeutic or diagnostic intervention; therefore the correct category is 'N/A'. Supporting published work on enhanced/multimedia consent in AD and similar populations further confirms the intervention type (examples cited). If you want, I can fetch the full clinicaltrials.gov record (NCT00453544) or the full-text publications. citeturn0search0turn0search1turn0search3

Web search results (sources found and used): 1) "Enhancing Consent for Alzheimer's Research" — trial listing with interventions noted as Enhanced Consent Procedure vs Routine Consent Procedure (MedPath / clinical-trial summary, NCT00453544). citeturn0search3 2) Grant summary "Enhancing Consent for Alzheimer Research" (Grantome / R01 abstract) summarizing aims and randomized design. citeturn0search2 3) PubMed: "Multimedia Aided Consent for Alzheimer's Disease Research" — randomized study evaluating multimedia enhanced consent and decisional capacity. citeturn0search0 4) PubMed / AJGP: "Comparison of Two Enhanced Consent Procedures for Patients With Mild Alzheimer Disease or Mild Cognitive Impairment" — related trial comparing enhanced consent formats. citeturn0search1
